page_analysis.text_content:
Grade

When measuring  | Use           | Which is defined as                                                                 | Illus.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The height of a structure on land with natural slope ≤ 10% | Existing Grade | for each building or structure, the lowest point of adjacent ground elevation prior to grading or fill | Fig 44 on this page

The height of a structure on land with natural slope > 10% | Grade         | adjacent ground elevation of the finished or existing grade, whichever is lower--at any point of the structure | Fig 45 on this page

A daylight plane | Average grade | average of the grade at the midpoint of the building and the grade at the closest point on the abutting site | Figs 20-21 pp. 26-27


Fig 44 Existing vs. Finished grade

Height measured to top of roof material of the highest peak
Finished grade (after fill)
Existing grade (before fill)
Lowest point of ground elevation before fill (existing grade) adjacent to the structure

Fig 45 Height limits for structures on slopes greater than 10%

30' above existing grade
30' above finished

The structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope

Fig 46 Comparison of different grades

visual_elements.description: A table with four columns: 'When measuring', 'Use', 'Which is defined as', and 'Illus.'. It lists three rows describing how to measure grade: for structures on land with natural slope ≤ 10%, > 10%, and a daylight plane, with corresponding definitions and figure references.

An architectural side elevation drawing of a house showing 'Existing vs. Finished grade'. It includes annotations for 'Height measured to top of roof material of the highest peak', 'Finished grade (after fill)', 'Existing grade (before fill)', and 'Lowest point of ground elevation before fill (existing grade) adjacent to the structure'.

A diagram illustrating height limits for structures on slopes greater than 10%. It shows two height limits: '30' above existing grade' and '30' above finished'. The diagram includes a sloped ground line with a house and arrows indicating height measurements. A note states: 'The structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope'.

A line graph titled 'Comparison of different grades' showing slope ratios and percentages: 1:10 (10%), 3:10 (30%), 5:10 (50%), and 10:10 (100%). The lines radiate from a common origin, illustrating different slope steepness.

technical_specifications.parameter: Natural slope for existing grade measurement
Height limit above existing grade on slopes > 10%
Height limit above finished grade on slopes > 10%

additional_notes: Page number 47 at bottom right corner.
All text is clear and legible with no visible handwritten annotations or stamps.
Figures and charts are clearly labeled with figure numbers and titles.

qualifiers.text: The structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope

logical_relationships.expression: The structure must comply with the lower of the two limits at all points along the slope
logical_relationships.ambiguity_note: The phrase implies a minimum height limit is the lesser of the two conditions, but exact logical operator is interpreted as AND with a minimum threshold.

execution_sequence.action: Determine natural slope of land to classify grade measurement method
If natural slope ≤ 10%, measure height from lowest point of adjacent ground elevation prior to grading or fill
If natural slope > 10%, measure height from adjacent ground elevation of the finished or existing grade, whichever is lower at any point of the structure
Ensure structure height does not exceed 30' above existing grade or 30' above finished grade, whichever is lower, at all points along the slope
